school nurse

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎09-06-2012 12:11 AM

Our new school nurse kept my son in her office for an hour today and an hour yesterday. She wanted to send him home. He did have high numbers, but what the heck? Give him some insulin and get back to class! Am I wrong? He was in the low 300s and it was after lunch.
Report Inappropriate Content

Re: school nurse

‎09-06-2012 11:19 AM

Do you have any paperwork from his doctor telling the school what to do when he has high numbers?  If they aren't following it, then you have a case.  If you don't have a detailed Medical Management Plan, get one asap!  In it, the doctor (with your help) can lay out how your son is to be treated for highs, lows, etc..  You'll probably find the nurse with the attitude that if it isn't in his medical plan, then she can't do it as she can only follow doctor's orders.(the plan)   And you might want to look into getting a 504 plan in place for him also.  Those are harder to get as alot of schools fight the kids having one even though they're entittled to one per the Americans with Disabilities Act.  Diabetes is considered a disability in how it effects kids and schoolwork.   It's just so many school are so not on board with complying with having one for their students with D.

 

 

 

 

 

 


Mother of Courtney, Dx'd Type 1 in 2006 at age 14.

Self: Dx'd "Pre"-Diabetic 8/8/14 *and we all know what that means*

Re: school nurse

Options

‎09-06-2012 11:25 AM

Hi I can't remember how old your son is or if he is on a pump or injections.  If he went to check his blood sugar before lunch and it was high, no ketones and he felt ok, the nurse should have had him bolus or cover for lunch and add correction and go eat and drink.  have him come back and check again in 2 hours.  Staying in the office is not going to accomplish anything.  If he felt crummy and ketones were present, then yes he probably needed to come home.  the first couple weeks of school are awful for trying to get blood sugar back on track.  there is the stress of school, new eating and sleeping patterns, allergy season, you name it.  Poking the kid's finger every 15 or 20 minutes is not going to accomplish anything for a high.  We really struggled with this in middle school.  our son was being held in the office off and on all day.  His grades suffered, he was stressed out and his teachers were no help.  We thought the nurse communicated to staff, but that was not happeneing.  Finally, unless it was a low or he felt crummy, we stopped blood sugar checks other than lunch.  By that time, his school day had become all about diabetes and not school.  We put the focus back on communicating with his teachers and not the nurse.  Now, he is 17.  Some days are good and some are not but school, sports etc do not stop over it.  Good luck and let us know how it turns out.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

G 18 diagnosed 3/22/08

‎09-06-2012 08:32 PM

I had similar issues even know I had a detailed format in which she should follow while my grand daughter was in school.She was newly diagnosed just last march,and she was the first student in that school with type 1 for the past 3 years.The nurse had to brush up on the information ,and I would get these calls that she had high B/S numbers and she asked me what to do,at that time I would tell her to dose her for it per what the sheet says,she would tell me the sheet dont specify how and when and how much to give her...as most of you know with children in school ,the sheet and medical paperwork is very precise and complete with all instructions that anyone in the medical field should be able to take care of...her answer was to sit her in the office and have her drink water and check her every 15 mins until she came down,I asked if this is the remedy then why the need for insulin to begin with.....I got tired of foolin with her and just would go pick my GD up from school beings it was the ending of the school year anyway......When I kooled down I had to go into the office and talk with the nurse and explain what exactly the med sheet was saying,she then understtod and I didnt really have as much problems after that....communication is the key here,if i couldnt communicate with GD school nurse and vice versa the only one suffering would be my grand daughter.....she has a 504 plan,matter of fact I go next wednesday to update it for this school year.........
